content.description: The middle overhang can be lightened by a small detour via hidden holds to the left.

This route trends right along a flake. Lieback the flake and pull past the reachy crux move to surmount the flake. Make sure to place a long runner on the 5th bolt to reduce rope drag. Once past that bolt immediately trend back to the left. Don't clip the 2 bolts to your right as you will be on FSR instead and will be wondering why the 10b you signed up for feels like 11 right before the anchors. Surmount the reachy roof move to gain the anchors.
Start right of the belay block. Once over the crimpy crux roof the jugs get bigger though the angle  does not relent.
Not much of a description in the local climbing guide. Hangars for belay are well below the top.

A fun but short pumpy route leading out of a large west facing corner. A start going to the left of the bolts is much easier than going over the top of bolts themselves and may lower the grade a little. Bolts are well placed and the climbing is pretty straightforward. Grade seems a little soft.
content.location: Located on the Lefthand side (facing the cliffs) of Upper Fifth Canyon. This route is the leftmost of three routes that begin at a detached Boulder in front of the cliff face. The approach is typical to get to Upper Fifth then traverse left and up to the cliff base.

content.description: A blocky climb that feels like it's just about to get hard, bet never does. Feels awkward and balancy, but has great hidden holds every time you need one.

A balancy climb that keeps you guessing. If it feels too hard look for better feet. The crux is about halfway up as you reach the arete. It looks like it's going to be hard. but go for it! the hold will be there.
content.location: Turn to the right as you climb down the Upper Fifth trail. It's the right-hand bolt line on the large, blocky arete North of the access trail. There are a pair of bolted climbs here. The one on the left is the Mangler (10a).

content.description: This is a great beginner route that has some really fun lieback moves throughout the climb. Start in the large corner and climb the crack to the top.
content.location: Just to the right of Lost Arrow Spur.

content.description: Described as a right of passage for local area climbers by some guide books. This is an excellent climb through mixed terrain. A little slab work combined with overhanging bulges make this route excellent. It is very well protected (actually a little over bolted) so is a good moderate lead. The crux is moving through some thin face moves after the first bulge is surmounted.
content.protection: 9 bolts/anchor - anchor is set a little back from the top
content.location: After descending the gully going into Upper Fifth canyon head to your left. This is the second climb on this side of the cliff as you head in and starts up some broken blocks. First bolt isn't far off the ground.

content.description:
A couple easy face moves past a standard bolt lead you up into a crack/flake/arete and a line of glue in bolts.   From here you can layback, jam, offwidth, face climb, or whatever suites you.  Lot's of sweet kneebars to be had.

I dont know who bolted this or FA but all the routes on this wall are well worth doing.  This wall has the best cluster of moderate routes at Post Falls and should get more traffic.  Don't miss them!
content.protection: 6 glue in bolts to chains.  Probably rap the route as there is a lot of rope drag.
content.location:
On Upper Fifth, Left Side.  Two routes to climbers left of gyno boy.  It's the far left route on the wall and the only one with glue-ins.  The guidebooks say a 5.11 used to be here but it appears that someone chopped it.

From left to right: missing/chopped 11, Layback?, Peter Beater, Project, Gyno Boy, the Mangler, Mangled up in Blue.

content.description: A fun little route that is a bit of a one move wonder. The crux is down low moving over a bulge. The top gets a little tricky your first time up (hint stay left of the bolt).
content.location: The first route on your right as you descend the gulley going into Upper Fifth Canyon.

climbs.name: Free Taters For Out Of Staters

content.description:
A great route! The start is steep and the first bolt is high. Unless you're very solid at the grade, I'd recommend bouldering up Lost Arrow to clip the first bolt, then lower down to start.

This is not a great TR route. I've got one friend with scars on his back from a TR fall at the crux.

The tree lurks just behind you, but is not a problem on lead.

A strenuous and steep start on good holds leads into sidepulls, slopers, and small crimps till you hit the next jug above the last bolt. The crux is at the fourth bolt. It's stout and not obvious.
content.location: The first route you get to on the East wall of the Upper Fifth. It's right behind the big tree.

content.description: This route moves through steep thin face moves down low. Then goes to low angle slab through the middle and finally tops out through a beefy bulge that requires some serious power. Great varied climb.You may want to put a longer runner on some of the lower bolts to avoid rope drag near the stout finish.
content.location: Just right of Spur of the moment.

content.description: Pulling the first roof is the crux. You get two holds that are just good enough to get you over the lip to a crimpy rail. Now you face a long move with no good feet to establish yourself on the vertical face. Fun and juggy over the second roof, you'll work up a good pump to the chains!
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains. ***NOTE*** you should bring a long draw or sling to place above the first roof. A standard draw will load the biner over the sharp roof edge!  and it's easy to fall here- kinda cruxy
content.location: Upper Fifth Canyon, left side, scramble 15' up to the ledge- Gyno Boy is third from the left.  Goes over two roofs- really steep roof start to clean vertical face.

content.description: Sharp crack to roof, traverse left under roof then exit up past the pine. Short route. This was rated 10a in the Northwest Passage guidebook but it felt more like 5.8 being able to get into fairly easy positions to place gear...maybe I was tall enough to be able to do so. Good moves in the beginning crack and pulling up past the small pine.
content.protection: Singles from BD C4 0.3 to 3 should be ok or small rack to 3 inches. Build an anchor far back from the ledge to bring your second up.
content.location: The route is located to the left of Ragnarock, the bolted route farthest left on Upper Fifth Canyon Left.

content.description: Begin in the large corner via LSH and climb the crack to a good shelf just over the buldge. Move left at the shelf and continue up bolts to the top. Moving (and clipping) through the first 2 bolts is the crux. Very thin and very steep.
content.protection: Gear for bottom crack (to 2 inches) then 4 bolts/rings.
content.location: Just right of Lost arrow Spur (see that route for instructions to get there).

content.description: The leftmost route.  Lots of barndooring.The overhang is most sport direct, but a rest and a cheat is possible out left. Endless jugs on steep rock. Like Hueco Tanks. Belay on top or use anchors as a directional to lower off on Looking Glass
Sustained through steep hidden jugs with an technical balancey start.
